objects.txt:
ACP: Delivery to stores in an optimal way

Automated case picking system, or ACP, provide the tools to outperform traditional order fulfillment methods.The improvements they bring not only benefit the distribution centre, but also boost the efficiency of the processes in the stores.
The Vanderlande ACP design is set up to allow modular growth and ensures availability by utilising parallel activities.
The service levels of a supermarket are extremely dependent on the quality and speed of its replenishment systems. 
All of the processes in a food retail distribution centre focus on delivering to the stores in an optimal way, while at the same time, working with maximum efficiency. Well-filled shelves are a very important factor in the shopping experience.  Replenishment personnel work quickly and efficiently to ensure that shoppers always find products at the right place, and are not hindered by pallets moving through the store. Invisible to the customer, there is much logic at work to make this process run smoothly.
Please take a look in our test environment.
objects.name: Info Card ACP General

objects.txt:
TUBTRAX is Vanderlande’s high-speed individual carrier system (ICS) solution for the rapid screening, processing,  transport and storage of baggage. 

It was the first ICS system in the world and Vanderlande’s systems are currently in operation at airports around the world, including Oslo, London Amsterdam, Vancouver, Jeddah and Istanbul.

The ICS method brings complete uniformity to the baggage handling  process, from self-bag drop to flight make-up, and for arrivals. Every item of baggage remains in the same individually controlled carrier, even during screening and storage, which helps to optimise  the  baggage handling process in line with the needs of all stakeholders.
objects.name: Info Card tubtrax main

objects.txt:
This testloop is made up of a transport loop that encloses the test circuit to the outside as a closed loop.
On the inside, the local areas take care of all the functionalities for baggage handling, like loading into tubs, unloading from tubs and stacking empty tubs.
Traffic to and from the main transport loop is handled by means of merge and divert modules.
objects.name: Info Card 2

The Tubtrax testloop consist of a main line transport loop, and local areas for functionalities like loading and unloading bagage, stacking empty tubs, Early Bag Store etc. Tubs are diverted from the main line onto a local area by means of a:

Tubtrax Divert

objects.txt: The Tubtrax dynamic unloader tilts the transport tub during transport, so that the baggage drops on to a raw baggage conveyor for further transport
objects.name: Info Card tekst unloader

objects.txt:
SMART ITEM ROBOTICS (SIR)

In the fast-changing and dynamic e-commerce market, omni-channel warehousing companies are continually looking for ways to run their operations more efficiently. They must maintain the highest level of service while meeting growing expectations from consumers. In addition, they must cope with increased order frequency and a growing number of smaller orders, and factor in the challenges associated with labour scarcity.

Robotic technology has made significant progress in recent years and is becoming a necessity for retailers in coping with consumer demand. As this technology continues to advance, it will become a more cost-effective and increasingly viable option. Smart item robotics (SIR) has been developed to help you deal with these challenges. It is a revolutionary solution that can handle dynamic product ranges without SKU teaching. Intelligent stacking enables the efficient positioning of goods, which reduces shipping costs.

With SIR, goods are handled smoothly and securely, which prevents them from being damaged. The solution can also be deployed in a flexible way by allowing for operator intervention as required. Supervision of multiple robotic item picking workstations by one operator is enabled by a simple and intuitive User Interface (UX).
objects.name: Info Card SIR

objects.txt:
FLEET is a flexible and sustainable baggage logistics solution. By using autonomous vehicle technology and intelligent software it enables the seamless handling of individual bags or ‘batches’ of bags (in uniform loading devices – ULDs – or carts) inside the baggage hall and up to the aircraft stands on the apron.

FLEET utilises a family of ‘runners’ – different types of autonomous vehicles that can be used both internally and externally. Due to FLEET’s system architecture, adding runners or changing routes is easy, resulting in a scalable and flexible solution. Sustainability is an integral part of the FLEET solution. A high level of attention has been paid to ergonomic considerations, safety and minimising energy consumption. The solution’s flexibility allows for the re-use of runners in other applications or locations. They can also be remanufactured and recycled, which contributes to a circular economy.
objects.name: Info Card

objects.txt: The fleet testsystem is under construction in the Innovation Centre,  this video shows FLEET-Bag in action at Lelystad Airport.
objects.name: Info Card 1

objects.txt: The Tubtrax loader module loads the bagage from above into the Tub. The unique code from the label is coupled to the tag number of the Tub for unique identification. The Radio Frequency ID tag is located on the bottom of the Tub and can be read by RFID readers located in between the twin belt transport system.
objects.name: loader Info

objects.name: Info Card main line 1

objects.txt: When less capacity is needed in the system, empty tubs can be stacked for temporary storage. If the needed capacity increases, tubs can be merged into the system after being made available by the destacker.
objects.name: Info Card Tub Stacker

objects.txt: Coming from the defoil station, the pallet is presented layer by layer to two operators, who manual distribute the products in to product trays. These are optimized for usage in the microshuttle warehouse and the palletizing robots. When a layer is done, the operator asks the hoist to lift the next layer. This is an optimized ergonomic solution for manua product handling from a pallet.
objects.name: Info Card manual depal

objects.txt: Incoming product pallets in the ACP system are manualy defoiled and logged into the IT system by an operator. From here they are transported with a hoist to either the manual depalletizing station, or to the automatix depalletizer positioned on a higher floor.
objects.name: Info Card defoil

objects.txt: Opposite to the manual depalletizing station we have a automatic depalletizing station. The layers are picked with vacuum technology and transferred to the conveyor system. From there, the products are singulated and transported to an automatic tray loading module.
objects.name: Info Card auto depal

objects.txt: Products that are singulized after automatic depalletizing are offered to the trayloader, which pushes the product into trays in picking unities, that can be handled by the microshuttle warehouse and the palletizing robots.
objects.name: Info Card tray loader

objects.txt: Trays with products are transported to this temporary storage. The DC footprint can been significantly reduced by using shuttle technology. The storage system uses highly dynamic shuttles, each of them travelling on a specific level in the storage rack. The shuttles use a combination of belts and telescopic forks to store and retrieve the products. This is a unique handling technique. Multiple products can be stored by location, optimized to the dimensions of the individual product. The retrieval of the products is carried out in a sequence that allows the downstream processes to build the outbound pallets exactly to the store’s requirements. Conveyors and elevators are used to combine the products that originate from different storage aisles, while following this sequence.
objects.name: Info Card storage

objects.txt: Load Forming Logic software is responsible for the definition of this optimal sequence and will also instruct the robotic palletisers on the exact positioning of the products on the pallet. The robotic palletiser starts by taking an empty pallet from a buffer. After a final check of the product properties, it will start stacking the products according to the planned methodology. A unique, omni-directional transfer (first Robot) allows the second robot to pick up the product in any direction required. The robot will adapt the handling speed and acceleration based on the properties thatwere defined at a Teach-in station to ensure that all products are handled safely. The load forming logic will ensure that the stacking patterns are stable and take into account the maximum weight that can be put on top of each product.
objects.name: Info Card robot palletizer

objects.txt:
Teach in Station.

In the automated distribution centre, the process starts with measuring the products at the Teach In station. From each typical product, dimensions, weight and various other properties are registered precisely to ensure the correct handling of the product in the automated processes.
objects.name: Info Card

objects.txt:
The sorter accelerates the crossbelt to divert the product into an output.
Different kinds of outputs can be used to match the wide range of products that can be handled. Products can also be sorted directly into mailbags, totes and roll cages. Different sort profiles can be selected, based on the measured positions and characteristics of the individual products. This ensures maximum sorting reliability and minimum output pitch.
objects.name: Info Card output

objects.txt: A barcode scanner or a RFID scanner reads the Licence Plate Number from a product tag attached to an item, and communicates this information to the equipment controller, which communicates it to high level controls. The barcode tag readers consists of multiple scanner heads, that scan for the barcode from one or multiple sides. RFID utilizes radio frequency techniques to access the tag. Within a scanner unit sometimes also dimensions and weights can be measured.
objects.name: Info Card Scanner
